ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: EDST family!
The partner essay assignment helped me evaluate my personal experience with education. It also helped me find out about my classmates and create connections across different aspects of education.
Community building with the EDST Cohort!
I learned how to care for myself better.
I learned to be myself, to be myself with others, and to build a classroom community that I care about and I feel cares for me back, and a community where everyone can be their full selves.

Throughout this course, I built really strong relationships with other new students in the ed studies program. I learned about a new way of approaching education from a place of resistance. We also learned about random things, like how to publish something in an academic journal and we got connected with ed studies alumni.

I built deep and meaningful connections with other peers in the 2023 cohort for Yale Education Studies Scholars Program. I connected to the same depth with the Cohort instructor.
I learned to connect my ongoing educational experience at Yale with my future involvement in public education. I learned to prioritize certain aspects of my educationrelationships, care, communityin a decolonial and anti-imperial lens. I learned about education as freedom, as song, as joy and as struggle.
I learned a lot about community building and what it takes to create a good and healthy education environment
I learned the importance of community in learning and how I ought to think about my education.
Education-related discussions, critical pedagogy skills, humane and compassionate teaching
that the people in my education studies cohort are amazing
I learned how to write and pursue publishing for an op-ed. I also learned what an amazing and inspiring community YES is!

The course challenged me to understand education and the motivations/forces driving it on a deeper level, to question/get the most out of my own educational experience, and to take the time to analyze how I plan to approach the education field. Incredible course!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It has no weaknesses!
I wish we had more time together. Often, our class time was instead used to attend EDST-wide events.

Strengths: 
- good vibe
- flexible schedule
Weaknesses:
- could have more structure

Strengths: 
- PROFESSOR TZB. PROFESSOR TZB. AND PROFESSOR TZB. JUST ABSOLUTELY HANDS DOWN ONE OF THE GREATEST PEOPLE I HAVE EVER MET. 
- the entire cohort. they are just absolutely amazing. i dont know how the department does it but they really just gather the like best people. 
- that we can come as we are and be our full selves, and that assignments have a purpose beyond a grade or the scope of the course. the assignments actually have meaning.
Literally no weakness, everything was wonderful

TZB organizes the class to make students feel valued, appreciated, seen, and respected. I always looked forward to our Wednesday night seminars because of our "come as you are" policy, which made me feel engaged and excited even when I was struggling with the semester or with personal things. This was a space of catharsis and healing and made me really excited about being in education. The readings were fantastic and really engaging.

this cohort class was amazing and i would take it a million times again. only thing i think could be improved is that there were a lot of talks that were at the same time as class which made it so there was like a month where we didnt meet, but that was more of a scheduling issue
The community built in this class was hands-down the most loving and positive space I've had in a Yale class.
A really good community building class, even in the virtual environment.
Extremely warm and welcoming community of Ed Studies Scholars, a great COVID-safe replacement for weekly dinners. TZB is the perfect person to lead this space

This is excellent. It feels somewhat unnecessary to provide an evaluation since all EDST scholars have to take this and no one else does, but it is certainly an excellent course and feels extremely worthwhile. I would say this class is one major way that the EDST scholars program feels a lot better than doing the certificate, and that is getting to do the projects and readings and community bonding with the other students in this class.

Strengths: The course was structured around what we as students wanted to do. It built such a strong, welcoming community among students and created a space where we could reflect on our experiences in education and ways we can improve it for others
Weaknesses: none
The emphasis on building community was immensely refreshing and often one of my favorite parts of the week.

This course is amazing. The strength of this course is the instructor. Professor TZB engaged and challenged us, and selected wonderful readings. She would often challenge us to sit in our own discomfort and would foster genuine input.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A success was leaving room for the students to cope by giving time at the beginning of class each week reflections and catching up.
The breakout rooms were always nice and fun, and the students organized some group study breaks/hangouts outside of the class which were awesome.

The variety of group sizes for different conversations (anywhere from 2 people in a break out room and the entire group in the main room) allowed for a wide variety of conversations with different people, which was definitely one of my favorite things from the class.
This course was awesome. Even though we were virtual, I felt like I was able to connect with my peers by discussing the readings and learning more about everyone's backgrounds and interests.
This course placed student mental health as a priority (check-ins, come as you are policy, syllabus adjustments, etc.) which was a moving thing to be a part of.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!! Its a wonderful introduction to the Education Studies Community.
If you are an EDST scholar, you will be required to take it and it will be a great time!!
Yes. This was a great way to build relationships with other education studies students.
YEP! APPLY TO ED STUDIES!!! BEST ACADEMIC THING AT YALE!!!
YES, it was so amazing.
Absolutely! TZB is wonderful/amazing/genius and will make you feel so validated. The community in this class is so wonderful (although this varies year to year of course).
Yes!!! Look forward to this as part of your ed studies requirements!!!
ABSOLUTELY JOIN EDUCATION STUDIES
For future cohorts, please please PLEASE savor every moment you have in this class. It's truly such a beautiful experience!
Yes! If you're thinking about joining the Ed Studies program, do it! It's such a good environment and you learn so much in a very constructive space.
Of course! Any course with TZB has my stamp of approval
Absolutely! The EDST community is like no other on campus, and this is the first step towards feeling like you're part of it.

I would absolutely recommend this course. The early readings of the course prompt discussions that really enabled us to get at the heart of what we feel need be changed about the way schooling is often done, and the unhealthy attitudes and mindsets many students fall into. There is also something immensely energizing about being able to build community and sense of belonging with other people interested in education.

YES! This course changed my life and my plan for how I will approach my education when I arrive back on campus. It will also serve as a consistent reminder to do the work and analyze the actions I take in a career in education in the future. Ed studies scholars are also incredible people to meet and interact with.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The discussion format enabled students to share information with each other. The personal connections helped foster a positive learning environment.
virtual seminar
n/a
live seminar, sometimes substituted with required EDST events
N/A
Virtual seminar once a week, occasionally replaced with a guest lecture at the same time, open to the general public.
N/a
collaborative project based learning
The primary mode of learning was a virtual seminar.
